qas.question: How do modern police often communicate?

answers.text: carried both on the person and installed in vehicles
to co-ordinate their work, share information, and get help quickly

qas.question: What have computers in police cars enabled for investigation?

answers.text: criminal background checks on persons of interest to be completed in a matter of seconds

qas.question: What have computers in police cars enabled for reporting?

answers.text: updating officers' daily activity log and other, required reports on a real-time basis

qas.question: What have computers in police cars disbled for reporting?

context: Modern police forces make extensive use of <a0_0><b5_0>radio<b5_0/><a0_0/> communications equipment, <a1_0><b6_0>carried both on the person and installed in vehicles<b6_0/><a1_0/>, <a2_0><b7_0>to co-ordinate their work, share information<b7_0/>, and get help quickly<a2_0/>. In recent years, vehicle-installed computers have enhanced the ability of police communications, enabling easier dispatching of calls, <a3_0><b8_0>criminal background checks on persons of interest to be completed in a matter of seconds<b8_0/><a3_0/>, and <a4_0><b9_0>updating officers' daily activity log and other, required reports on a real-time basis<b9_0/><a4_0/>. Other common pieces of police equipment include flashlights/torches, whistles, police notebooks and "ticket books" or citations.
